action.action-desc: Mr. McCormick introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs

form.official-title: To require certain bureaus of the Department of State and the United States Agency for International Development to release quarterly reviews of certain grants, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Assessing Unintended Drivers of Illegal Trafficking Act or the AUDIT Act.

section.header: Latin America migrant services grant transparency

subsection.text: The Department of State’s Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration shall:

paragraph.text: Issue a quarterly report documenting all the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration grant money spent on migrant and asylum-seeker programs in Central and South America. The report shall explain why each implementing partner was chosen, the amount of money it received, the availability of asylum claim processing in the countries in which those partners operate, and the number of claims processed in those countries. The report shall include—

subparagraph.text: grants given to non-governmental organization implementing partners which are building asylum shelters or creating asylum processing capacity in Central and South America;
grants given to implementing partners conducting casework, counseling, or legal representation for asylum seekers; and
grants given to implementing partners providing other services to asylum seekers, including transportation, monetary assistance, and housing.

paragraph.text: Be prohibited from giving grants to implementing partners which provide abortion services to asylum seekers. This includes implementing partners—

subparagraph.text: providing sexual and reproductive health services that include referrals to receive abortions;
providing assistance in obtaining abortions;
providing the abortion procedure itself; and
which directly or indirectly fund abortions or services for obtaining abortions in any manner for asylum seekers.

subsection.text: The Department of State’s Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor shall:

paragraph.text: Issue a quarterly report documenting all the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor grants given to migrant and asylum seeker rights programs in Central and South America. The report shall explain why each implementing partner was chosen, the amount of money it received, the availability of asylum claim processing in the countries in which those partners operate, and the number of claims processed in those countries. The report shall include—

subparagraph.text: direct grants from the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor to migrant shelters;
grants to non-governmental organization implementing partners that provide grants or programming to other non-governmental organizations or migrants rights organizations;
the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor programming for building local asylum processing capacity or improving institutional transparency or efficiency;
grants given to implementing partners conducting casework, counseling, or legal representation for asylum seekers; and
any other programs the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor funds for the purpose of promoting migrant or asylum seeker rights.

paragraph.text: Be prohibited from giving grants to implementing partners who provide abortion services to asylum seekers. This includes implementing partners—

subparagraph.text: providing sexual and reproductive health services that include referrals to receive abortions;
providing assistance in obtaining abortions;
providing the abortion procedure itself;
who directly or indirectly fund abortions or services for obtaining abortions in any manner for asylum seekers; and
which directly or indirectly fund abortions in any manner for asylum seekers, provisions, or assistance in obtaining an abortion.

subsection.text: The United States Agency for International Development shall:

paragraph.text: Issue a quarterly report documenting all the United States Agency for International Development grants given to migrant, asylum seeker, and internally displaced persons programs in Central and South America. The report shall explain why each implementing partner was chosen, the amount of money it received, the availability of asylum claim processing in the countries in which those partners operate, and the number of claims processed in those countries. The report shall include—

subparagraph.text: direct grants from the United States Agency for International Development to migrant shelters;
grants from the Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance to implementing partners in the region working with migrants and asylum seekers;
prosperity, security, and governance grants given to El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras;
integration grants to Belize, Costa Rica, and Panama;
grants given to resettle and integrate Venezuelans outside their country and grants to implementing partners operating within Venezuela;
grants or programs related to messaging to citizens of Central and South America; and
grants given for governmental institutional capacity building.

paragraph.text: Be prohibited from giving grants to implementing partners which provide abortion services to asylum seekers. This includes implementing partners—

subparagraph.text: providing sexual and reproductive health services that include referrals to receive abortions;
providing assistance in obtaining abortions;
providing the abortion procedure itself;
who directly or indirectly fund abortions or services for obtaining abortions in any manner for asylum seekers; and
which directly or indirectly fund abortions in any manner for asylum seekers, provisions, or assistance in obtaining an abortion.

subsection.text: The reports by the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor, and the United States Agency for International Development shall begin the quarter after this legislation is enacted.
